newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: UN panel sees no change on Iraq oil deal delays.
newsitem.headline: UN panel sees no change on Iraq oil deal delays.

text.p: The UN Security Council Sanctions Committee on Iraq was told Monday implementation of the oil-for-food plan continued to be delayed due to security concerns in the northern Kurdish regions of the country.
A U.S. official on the panel told reporters there were no major actions taken by the panel during Monday's meeting.
The offical reiterated that nothing has changed since last week when top UN officials said conditions to implement the limited sales deal remained untenable.
Implementation of the limited oil plan has been delayed since September 1.
At that time, UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali delayed deployment of UN staff meant to monitor oil sales and aid distribution under the plan.
The U.S. official also said the committee once again deferred a decision on a Turkish request to buy Iraqi oil as an exception to the oil-for-plan.
The official said the Turkish request would be dealt with after the oil plan was implemented.

Also on Monday's agenda were requests by Iraq for what the U.S. official termed "non-humanitarian aid," notably an $18 million request for the oil industry to repair equipment, as well as a request to increase funds from the oil plan to pay for crude production and trasportation costs.
The U.S. official said no action was taken on these requests, and noted the oil-for-plan does not include provisions for infrastructure and transportation expenditures.
The oil-for-food accord would allow $2 billion in oil sales every six months to be as humanitarian relief for the Iraqi populace suffering under UN-imposed sanction after Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990.
